reviewText: If you've played Pony Island then you have played a much better version of this game.\n\nCalendula has the same basic premise as Pony Island: Try and play a broken game that doesn't want to be played. The game" plays out like an indie short film with bizarre imagery and a pretensious "plot". The entire game consists of about 15 very simple puzzles mixed in with some nonsensicle cut scenes of raw meat in a sink. If Calendula's aim is to be creepy
date: it failed. If Calendula's aim was to deep
recommended:
it failed.

Is it a digital representation of reincarnation?
A metaphor for the creative process of making a game?

I don't know.

But oh well
hoursPlayed: It is not my fault.\n"

reviewText: I really liked the concept of a haunted video game ala PonyIsland/Undertale, but the game isn't even an hour long and the puzzles are way too simple.
voteText: 50 of 72 people (69%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText: An excellent and unique experience, there is no game quite like Calendula. For a game that is mostly made of seemingly broken features and insane surreal glitches, it tells a fairly coherent and enjoyable story. Even if you're not in it for the story, it's still a supreme mind-screw. The puzzles are brain-tingling but solvable, and each time I solved one I felt like I'd done something incredibly wrong.\n\nNote the short playtime, but also know that the game is expertly paced and just the right length for the type of experience it delivers. If you want to feel truly bewildered and slightly uncomfortable, then this game is definitely for you. It never let me get my bearings, and it was over before I knew what happened. I love it.

reviewText: I hate to have to say this... I really do. I loved the game... but I cannot recommend it to people, especially at the current price tag it has. The game is good, it has great atmosphere to it and its all psychological in its presentation. I love games like that. The problem here... its too short. You can get through it all well within 30 to 40 minutes and thats the game. If the price drops... I do recommend a playthrough of it then. especially if it  was on sale for a dollar. That feels like a more acceptable price tag for a game that has no real replay value. No, i am not trying to bash the makers of this game. As i said before, I loved it and I love the concept of it, its just... -way- too short. ONLY get this... if you have enough money to just blow on something you are only going to play through once, if you are willing. otherwise, give it a pass.

reviewText: 559 products in account
date:
Well, that.. certainly wasn't what I expected from this game.

Not only that it had just one hour of playtime at best, but most of this time is spend in the main menu, where you have to solve a bunch of easy puzzles. After solving one you get to walk a few meaningless steps in a meaningless corridor and see some really meaningless pictures, which are meant to be disturbing. There also are creepy sound effects all the time, which at least have a better impact than the rest. I guess you could say that the screenshots on the Steam shop page already spoiler you most of the game's content.

I would've recommended CALENDULA if it was free. But I paid 6$ for this, which is far too much. Well, at least I can refund it right away after I bought it.

(P.S.: If you're looking for a game that twists your mind, I can highly recommend The Stanley Parable. It's great.)

reviewText:
Deliberately glitchy, unstable and constantly fracturing, Calendula is hot on the heels of the recent Pony Island for the most meta game of 2016.

We must manipulate a broken menu screen to be able to play the horror game 'Calendula'. But the game resists being played, actively evading the player with its constantly shifting commands.

It takes the broken menu puzzles of Pony Island and makes a complete experience of them. Thanks to the sheer originality of its execution, it's effective and engaging, and Calendula conjures up plenty of opressive tension through its disconcerting atmosphere.

Between puzzle sloving there are surreal first person vignettes which form the actual game" of Calendula that we're trying to play. These sections add to the disturbing vibe rather than give any real exposition or narrative
date: until later when we're beat over the head with the obvious symbolism.\n\nUltimately it's up to the player to decide "what it all means"
recommended: and I concluded with a story that works for me
hoursPlayed: although that narrative doesn't connect with the mechanics of the game in any meaningful way. They feel like seperate experiences.\n\nStill
voteText: it's a sharp and mysterious atmospheric-puzzler
helpfulPercent: even if it's intended mind-♥♥♥♥ doesn't quite come together with its mechanics in unity."

reviewText:
This is a great little meta game, that messes with your mind, and also encourages you to think. You want to start the game so much, but you can't because the game refuses to be played. So it will do everything to stop you. It will crash itself many times. It will mess with the settings. It will show you things to distract you, and most of all, it will make you look like an idiot. It's a clever game that will keep you thinking, even after it is over.

If you want to see what's in store for you, you can look at my gameplay video here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ExfYpZ1Ybe0

reviewText:
If you want to enjoy, just plug your headphones and play it. Stop reading this.

In case you want to know about my opinion keep reading.

This game isn't an horror game. This game isn't a puzzle's game. This game isn't a videogame at all.
It's a complete experience. An experience that will play with your senses and the way you think.

You won't know what's happening. You won't even know if your senses are working properly. Eventually you will realise that each test that develepers set in the game has a meaning. That they are playing with your mind and the way you pass each test.

You cannot beat the game, you discover it.

reviewText: I never thought I would be saying I actually enjoyed a game in which I literally cannot get past the main menu, but I guess anything is possible now. I wasn't sure what to expect when I bought this game, and Calendula surprised me in more than one way. It's hard to say much without spoiling the overall experience, which I would hate to do. It's really a game you have to try for yourself, and play along with wholeheartedly in order to truly enjoy the ride. I've never played a game quite like it, and find it impossible to compare it to anything else.\n\nSometimes, there are more to games than reaching clear goals or defeating obvious enemies. Sometimes games have a more subversive message. And, sometimes, games just like to mess with your head and haunt your dreams. Calendula is one of those games.

reviewText:
Below is a review  of Calendula and comparison similar game Pony Island

Both Calendula and the more well know Pony Island have come out recently and both games are similar in the sense they are ‘Meta’ puzzle games featuring a self-aware game that is trying to stop you from being able to play it.

Calendula which on the face of it  is a bit less flashy than Pony Island and definitely less complicated. In Calendula you are trying to play a game and load save files. Most of the save files are password protected and you must do a number of different tasks to work out each password whilst the self-aware game tries to screw with you.

Every time you manage to load a save file you walkthrough a small section of trippy horror game before being kicked back out to the main screen. The best way I can describe the visual style of this game is a computer game version of the video in the Ring. Put it this way I am going to be keeping an eye on any wet pale dark haired girls for the next few weeks.

The key difference to Pony island is the puzzles in Calendula are a little bit less like puzzles and more working things out by manipulating the menu screens and playing with the settings. While I can see a lot of people will find this game a lot more simplistic than Pony Island I actually found the more natural less contrived puzzles of this game more enjoyable than the more obvious puzzles of Pony Island.

So which one to play? Both games are good and well worth a play through and both are different enough to warrant some attention on their own merits. Both are cheap and neither outstay their welcome. If you must pick Pony Island is a little bit more of a puzzle game and Calendula is more of a detective game.

Both however are good fun that I would definitely recommend picking up if you fancy something a little bit different.

Please check out our comparison video below if you would like to know more...

http://www.thegametutor.co.uk/videos/game-tutor-compares/160207_game-tutor-compares-pony-island-and-calendula

A KEY FOR THE GAME WAS OBTAINED FROM THE DEVELOPER BUT MY VIEWS AND OPINIONS ARE 100% MY OWN.

reviewText:
If you don't know anything about Calendula, I envy you. Just play it before someone spoils it.

This is one of those game where you don't see the 4th wall at all.

Visually it has its own personality, and it's really beautiful in a disturbing way. But the big point about Calendula is its impressive atmosphere, even better if you play through in one sitting, with lights off and a good pair of headphones.

It's a short experience that will stay in your head for a couple of days.

If you liked The Stanley Parable, Pony Island or Dr. Langeskov, you'll like Calendula.

reviewText: This is basically the Inception of video games. So complicated and weird that your initial response is to think it must be good, because ultimately it's too weird for you to figure out. So we pretend we understand, and that we all like it, in an attempt to appear intelligent. The truth, though, is that the game is empty of meaning; that it just avoids having any substance in favor of confusing you so much that you think it does have something to it. It really, really, doesn't. There's going to be discussion of this game the same way there was discussion of Inception, people arguing about wha ♥♥♥ meant, and what the ending actually is. It's not really anything. I will say the puzzles were superb, but all of the buildup with plot and atmosphere were meaningless, in the end. If you like puzzles, go for it, but if you'll get invested in trying ot figure out what's going on, take a pass on this one.

reviewText: One of the many Steam games I've played that makes me wish there was some kind of in between rating I can gave other than the Caesarish Yea" or "nay." Since I must
date: I have to lean more towards wanting to enjoy the "game
recommended:
but it simply wasn't for me.

Many will point out the heavy borrowing from the Pony Island concept and they're not wrong, but it's not a reason alone to dislike Calendula. Yes there a many completely original games out there, and there have and always will be games that borrow concepts from those before it. It's not a big deal, because so many great games take these concepts and do something great with them. Sometimes it's a new twist. Sometimes it's an incredible story. There's a myriad of things you can do with a borrowed concept to elevate it. Calendula did so very little to try.

The atmosphere was fun and the puzzles were pretty decent. Other than that, it's incredibly short (50 minutes without much brain stuggle,) and it doesn't have much plot or heft to hold the package up. Not a regretful playthrough at all, but I have a hard time recommending it.

reviewText:
If you're a fan of games like Pony Island or Imscared or any other 'meta' game that tries to manipulate your gaming experience than you'll probably enjoy this.
Not very scary, but the 'puzzles' were quite inventive and made a fairly interesting playthrough.
The theme, although not clear at first, was also a nice touch.

Please keep in mind though that it takes less than an hour to complete and there is little replayability.

reviewText: I enjoyed Calendula for the forty minutes it lasted. Or rather, I thought I was enjoying where it was going. Every time you complete a puzzle you get a small walking section (where you can only go straight, and the game turns you through glitches if necessary) followed by a brief fmv clip. I'm going to spoil the twist" in this review
recommended: its Shyamalan levels of dumb.\n\nAt the beginning of each level you are booted back to the main menu screen. That much you probably already know. The majority of gameplay takes place here. This is where the game is at its best. It's extremely fun to solve abstract puzzles that ♥♥♥♥ with your perception of the menus
hoursPlayed: the space around them
voteText: and the ambient audio. It's all very interesting
helpfulPercent: and I absolutely love it during this
votesHelpful: even if it is a tad too easy.\n\nOnce you solve the puzzle
votesTotal: you get a walking segment. The environments differ each time
votesFunny: but they're always fairly basic corridors. After the walking is where it gets juicy. At some point during the walk glitches will appear and the game will fade into an unsettling fmv clip that implies more is going on.\n\nThe game has a ton of eye imagery
commentsCount: some are photorealistic during the transition to fmv. One puzzle has you go into an ingame fake chat room where somebody screams at you to "please stop" and asks why you're doing "this"
column16: then repeating "WHY" repeatedly before he 'logs off'. At one point during a walking section you approach a globe
column17: and it darkens as you approach
column18: almost seeming to mold. The game seems to be about some large world government

column21: I hear you ask? None of the above. You're a kid named Calendula being born. The ending is atrocious.\n\nI was honestly tempted to refund this game
column22: but seeing as how I absolutely adored the puzzle section
column23: I've decided to leave my money with Blooming Buds. I loved your game
column24: but don't lead me on with a story. Next time you guys make a game
column25: include a narrative that isn't a bunch of disconnected parts that can't be related to each other
column26: okay? The ending is what REALLY brought this down."

reviewText: This game tries very hard to be 'artsy' and deep but there's just not a lot to it.  The gameplay is mildly interesting, similar to some parts of Pony Island.  However it's lacking a coherent story, fun, or any good reason for what you're doing or seeing.  If you're into avant garde art maybe you'll like this.  Personally I felt like it was trying way too hard to be weird and not enough on immersing the player or creating any sort of engaging story.\n\nIf the concept of playing a game that doesn't want to be played sounds cool, do yourself a favor and get Pony Island instead.

reviewText:
A fantastic game artistically, a great experience, a creepy inmersion.

It is a total different style against what we see today, a brilliant idea mixed with exceptional art and puzzles that will make you want to throw a punch to the screen.
If you do not go through this, you do not know where video games are today. Old.

I recommend playing it with headphones and loud, to increase by 100 the experience.
Take my money.
10/10.

reviewText: It's true what you've heard; Calendula is not a game, but more of an experience. What's really clever is the way that the developers were able to create a viable adventure based solely around configuration menus. I don't know about any of you, but some of my first few minutes (if not hours) with a video game I've purchased online, are spent adjusting my settings in order to get everything fine tuned to my liking. This game built upon that compulsion and added a goal and a story... honestly, I'm just flat impressed.\n\nFrom sound to presentation, you're not going to be disappointed. Definitely worth the buy.

reviewText:
CALENDULA lasted for me, roughly 30 minutes.
This is NOT a scary game, but it is creepy, and  It is not very difficult.
If you like the color red or changing menu options you may like this game.
Other than that, the 3d portions of the game are you walking straight down a hallway with the W key.
Again, I beat this game in 30 minutes, 5/8 achievements.

reviewText:
Honestly, do not read any reviews if you truly want to enjoy this game to its full potential!

The following is my opinion after completing it:

I was definitely not expecting this game to be the way it is. Short and simply put, this is a game that does not want to be played. At first you will be confused, and slowly begin to catch onto the erie atmosphere and feel of being trapped in a game that is trying its best to keep you. The only way to progress is to catch onto the subtle hints that guide you along the way.

I won't say much more about this game". It is outstanding how strange Calendula is
date: and frightening how unique a style of gameplay can be when simple mechanics are initiated. It is not a horror game or puzzle game - in a strict sense
recommended:
it is not a game at all. It's a odd experience you really just have to play to understand.

reviewText: I'd love to sit here and tell you what I played, but there are no words.  Not for the terrifying imagery, nor for the chills down my spine from the anxiety it put me through.  What you encounter is extremely meta and there's really no game here...only an experience that you must put yourself through.  Spoiling anything in a review will only devalue your experience.  What I can say is that the best experience is with headphones on and in a dark room.

reviewText:
Only 8 minutes in, and this game is creeping me the ♥♥♥♥ out.

Very meta stuff, complete with gameplay screws and possibly fake crashes as well.

Think Eternal Darkness, but more focused on meta and you being the avatar here.

The best way to describe Calendula is a series of mind games and puzzles the game throws at you.
Every aspect of the game can be used to solve a puzzle. The objective in each puzzle is to open the game. Every time you open a new game, an error will be thrown your direction, and you'll have to figure out what to do to play the game.

The puzzles themselves are fairly simple, but some can be complex, especially when taking in interface screws that crop up over time.

Overall, a very meta game that is for people who enjoy mindgames and puzzles.

reviewText: I really liked the puzzles and atmosphere of this game. Unfortunately I think the ending is bad and it's also really short. I beat it in about an hour. Go into it blind and don't expect much from the story. I thought it would end with some really interesting horror story but it's just not there.\n\nOh and you may run into issues if you run multiple monitors. It uses the left monitor even if you have your right monitor set as your main one.  A little annoying. Only fix I could find was going into display settings on Windows and changing my layout around.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I had gone into this game thinking 'Well, people keep comparing it to Pony Island so let's see.' It is pretty much that.

Only that Pony Island gave more of a story, better atmosphere and a MUCH LONGER playing time. I beat the game in 1 hour. I had been expecting to get more out of the game. The puzzles weren't too hard to figure out. I got stopped for several minutes on one of them.

I enjoyed it but it was lacking too much for me to have really truly had fun. And the imagery was just... Weird. Steak in a sink? That one confused me. And the 'glitchy' environment was a little spooky at first but then it got a little cliche after the first few levels.

Honestly, for the price it is at, even with the sale, I can't really give this too good of a rating. I could get more spookies out of The Park for a couple more dollars, honestly.

reviewText: This game is absolutely amazing. I was very iffy at first and nearly decided not to buy this but I had this gut instinct to give the game a shot. The entire game acts like one big puzzle in order to eventually play the game" all while giving you glimpses of what the game is supposed to be right before throwing some grotesque image on the screen and restarting. Some of the puzzles make sense while some really require you to think about what this game is wanting from you. I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for something a little new to try out. IF you sill aren't sure I have a gameplay video of this interesting game:\n\nhttps://youtu.be/Boqw3z2qbDs"

reviewText: I would suggest taking this game with a little pinch of salt. The game is less 'meta' and more just plain glitchy. It's fun, and the puzzles are a great mixture between challenging, do-able, and unnerving, and the music in particular was very good, as were some of the visual elements (although not all of it- it runs on Unity, after all). But it is not horror. It's definitely creepy in parts, and if you have an aversion to glitching or technology with slight self-awareness then this may get you feeling a little panicked. What ruins it, however, is the storyline element, which is a little contrived, the allegory a little forced, and the ending less of a big spooky bang and more of a tired mumbling of Oh
recommended: definitely. It's a nice little indie game with a lot of atmosphere
hoursPlayed: which for the most part makes up for any downfalls."
voteText: February 2

reviewText:
Calendula is a surreal experience and sort-of puzzle game. It will appeal to you if you're the kind of person that dives straight into the options menu when you first launch a game.

Clendula pits you in a fight with the game itself in an effort to actually play" it. It will mess with you every way a game can in order to not be played. You're going to have to use your accumulated knowledge of in-game menus to win this one.

That said
date: I enjoyed this game quite a bit. In terms of music and tone
recommended: Calendula nails it. The only thing I can complain about is the short length. I beat it in about 45 minutes
hoursPlayed: but I completed it feeling satisfied."

reviewerDisplayName: The Guy Who Framed Roger Rabbit
reviewText:
I RECOMMEND THIS ONLY IF YOU CAN GET IT CHEAP

It's worth throwing five bucks at but that's really about it.


The idea is solid and the puzzles are fun. I got hung up in the eyeroom but Alt-F4ing and reopening it fixed it.

Over all the concept was solid. I really enjoyed the game and its subtle unerving atmosphere. The puzzles were interesting but not hard which was a nice touch. I beat it in about two hours.

My main gripe is the plot which ends, in my opinion, in a way that feels way too cliche. I won't spoil it but, as your going through, if you've played other indie games out there, you're more than likely going to figure out how it ends pretty quickly.

6-7/ 10  Is what I say. Great idea, concept, and excecution with pretty cool sound design to boot. The main problem being the story, which, unfortunatly in a game like this, seems a bit weak.

reviewText:
After a hard working day at the office writing emails and texts maybe calling in for support you come home and might explore if there is something mor sinister out there in the world.
And in playing this game you'll find it.

After starting the game I originally wanted to contact the Steam-support but gladly asked Google before.

Regarding the game I admit the different styles of creating fear and horror. Th game for itself combines several kind of artistic styles in an interresting way.
Also the subtle differences of the vein durinf the game-progress are great.

At least I can say that this game defines the art of horror in a complete new way.

It's quite a short game but worth the few bucks they demand.


I highly suggest playing this game - especially after a hard working-day at the office!

reviewText: You'll find yourself reminded a lot of Pony Island while playing this game.  It leans heavily on inspiration into the world of metaphysics, and you find yourself questioning whether Calendula is a malevolent or benevolent entitiy.  The puzzles were clever, and I enjoyed the unsettling atmosphere.  It will take you about 50 minutes to play through the entire thing, so I definitely wouldn't say it's worth $7, but it's a great experience.  The ending will have you thrown.  The entire point of the game is definitely unclear, and the cutscenes" (points in the game in which you simply move forward through rooms) seem to be unconnected
date: but the atmosphere gives me shivers.\n\nLess of a game
recommended: more of an experience that you interact with.  However
hoursPlayed: that is definitely not a bad thing."
